nodes.bodyText: This isn't an equivalent comparison.
Please check the new version.
wouldn't a null be more appropriate here than an empty string?
I don't think this provides additional information. Since this is displayed to the user, an empty string is closer to having no message than "null".
No @Override annotation?
HttpResponse can't accept a null message?
Interesting. I reverted that change quite some time ago and made HttpResponse acceppt null-strings. Please check again.
Looks like there are two different HttpResponse classes. One in org.openhab.io.neeo and another in org.openhab.binding.neeo...
This change isn't equivalent. Would there by any consequences from setting these values to 0?
0 means no delay. This is for sure better than crashing.
Wouldn't it be better to change NetworkUtils.singleError to accept a null message?
Maybe add a message for the NumberFormatException here, the catch would end up using it.
System.err can be null!?
https://github.com/AdoptOpenJDK/openjdk-jdk11/blob/19fb8f93c59dfd791f62d41f332db9e306bc1422/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/System.java#L155
I hope this doesn't cause problems...
What would you suggest as an alternative?

Change the return type of getDurationInMinutes to OptionalLong or Optional<Duration> and then adjust the code in VehicleHandler accordingly. Using an Undef state should suffice for the situation where it is missing.

Should probably log something here, looks like there is an expectation for the browseTarget to be logged for debugging. I'd suggest logging a message here regarding the lack of an entry for that browseTarget.
If the logDir is not in the system properties I think it would be safer for this binding if you put the thing offline with a configuration error.
I was thinking about that. But finally decided to put it in the if-clause because I think that a null value here is some sort of error state and the thing should probably not be ONLINE.
Should you return if you find a null thingTypeUID? Is it ok to create a ThingUID with a null thingTypeUID?

I just tested to make sure and confirmed that this isn't an equivalent change. findFirst() will throw an NPE if the first element it encounters is a null value, so you need to filter out the null values before you can do the mapping.
Perhaps it's better to move this to the POMs in bundles and itests because there won't be any unpacked EEAs in other projects such as bom/features.

nodes.bodyText:
It will build better with:

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                                            logger.info("Browse target not found. Exiting.")
          
          
            
                                            logger.info("Browse target not found. Exiting.");
obviously.

It would be so much easier to read when statically importing Map.entry and using entry( instead of all those lengthy new AbstractMap.SimpleEntry<AlertLevel, String>( constructs here. 😆
private static final Map<AlertLevel, String> ALERT_COLORS = Map.ofEntries(
            entry(AlertLevel.GREEN, "00ff00"),
            entry(AlertLevel.YELLOW, "ffff00"),
            entry(AlertLevel.ORANGE, "ff6600"),
            entry(AlertLevel.RED, "ff0000"),
            entry(AlertLevel.UNKNOWN, UNKNOWN_COLOR));
Since we will not backport to 2.5.x we could also use Map.of. But I think changing all this is beyond the scope here.
I just hope a casual reader learns something from it so there will be less of these monstrosities in the future. :-)

Using anything else besides annotations from the org.eclipse.jdt.annotation package will likely cause runtime issues because these packages are considered to be optional:

  
    
      openhab-addons/pom.xml
    
    
         Line 142
      in
      9a5832a
    
    
    
    

        
          
             org.eclipse.jdt.annotation.*;resolution:=optional,\\ 
        
    
  


I think currently it is only safe to use the Checks class in test code.
It work without. I wonder why I added it. Also fixed some potential NPE while looking through the binding.
